name: phthalonitrile
Reason: The target compound, phthalonitrile, consists of a basic benzene ring with two nitrile groups attached. The basic benzene ring has a melting point of approximately 5.5°C. Each nitrile group has the tendency to increase the melting point due to strong dipole-dipole interactions and potential for hydrogen bonding with other molecules, although there are no hydrogen bond donors in phthalonitrile itself. Since nitrile groups are electron-withdrawing, they contribute significantly to the rigidity and planarity of the molecule which also raises the melting point. I estimate that each nitrile group would add about 65°C to the melting point of benzene.

name: phthalonitrile
Reason: The compound phthalonitrile includes a benzene core which normally has a melting point of approximately 5.5°C. The presence of two nitrile groups significantly influences the melting point. Nitrile groups are strong dipoles and can engage in dipole-dipole interactions, thus substantially raising the melting point. The electron-withdrawing nature of the nitrile groups increases the rigidity of the molecule, further contributing to a higher melting point. The quantified effect of each nitrile group, based on similar compounds and considering these interactions, might be approximately 67.25°C (which when added to the benzene baseline and multiplied by two gives the closest approximation to the actual melting point).
